EUVpy.tools.toolbox module

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.band_info(bin_boundaries_left, bin_boundaries_right, solomon=False)[source]

Given a two array-likes of wavelength bin boundaries, return the indices of those corresponding only to wavelength ranges, rather than individual lines, and also return the wavelength boundaries themselves.

Parameters:

  • bin_boundaries_left (arraylike) – The left-sided wavelength band boundaries. May either be in nm or Angstroms.

  • bin_boundaries_right (arraylike) – The right-sided wavelength band boundaries. May either be in nm or Angstroms. Units should match those of bin_boundaries_left.

  • solomon (boolean) – If True, does the same thing, but accounts for overlapping bands in the solomon bins. Default is False.

Returns:

  • sortInds (arraylike) – The indices of the wavelength ranges only.

  • xPosSorted (arraylike) – The values of the wavelength ranges themselves, for the purposes of making spectral stair plots.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.bestPolyfit(xdata, ydata, maxOrder=5, func=None, **kwargs)[source]

Given independent variable and dependent variable 1D data fit the data with polynomial functions of orders up to a user-defined limit set to ‘maxOrder’. For the best-fitting model, return the parameters for the polynomial (as a poly1d object) along with the associated Residual Sum of Squares.

Parameters:

  • xdata (numpy.ndarray) – 1D independent variable data.

  • ydata (numpy.ndarray) – 1D dependent variable data.

  • maxOrder (int) – A number below which (inclusive) to consider models to fit to the data. Default is 5.

  • func (str) – Specifies what function should be used for fitting. Valid strings are: ‘exp’, ‘linear’, ‘log’, and ‘cubic’. If this argument is passed, maxOrder is ignored.

Returns:

modelRes – A list where the first element are the model parameters, the second is the Residual Sum of Squares, and the third is the model order.

Return type:

list

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.binCorrelation(xdata, ydataEst, ydataTrue, step=10, saveLoc=None, titleStr=None, root=False, normalize=False)[source]

Given some 1D independent variable data, some 1D estimates of dependent variable data, 1D true values of dependent variable data, and a step size, divide the xdata into bins of width equal to the step size and compute the squared difference in each bin. Then compute the correlation between the the squared difference and the binned xdata. Automatically saves a figure for the results at a user-defined location.

Parameters:

  • xdata (numpy.ndarray) – 1D independent variable data.

  • ydataEst (numpy.ndarray) – 1D estimates of dependent variable data.

  • ydataEst – 1D actual values of dependent variable data.

  • step (int) – The bin width for the independent variable data. Default is 10.

  • saveLoc (str) – A string for the location where the figure should be saved.

  • titleStr (str) – A string for the title of the figure to be generated. Assumes that a single number representing a figure number or wavelength is given.

  • root (Bool) – Controls whether the square root of the SQDF is taken. Default is False.

  • normalize (Bool) – Controls whether the SQDF is normalized (by dividing by the true data and multiplying by 100). Default is False. If True, ignores the value of ‘root’.

Returns:

  • binCenters (list) – The bin centers for the dependent variable data.

  • SQDF (list) – The Squared Difference values for each bin.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.binRMSE(xdata, ydataEst, ydataTrue, step=10, saveLoc=None, titleStr=None, normalize=False)[source]

Given some 1D independent variable data, some 1D estimates of dependent variable data, 1D true values of dependent variable data, and a step size, divide the xdata into bins of width equal to the step size and compute the RMSE error in each bin. Then compute the correlation between the RMSE and the binned xdata. Automatically saves a figure for the results at a user-defined location.

Parameters:

  • xdata (numpy.ndarray) – 1D independent variable data.

  • ydataEst (numpy.ndarray) – 1D estimates of dependent variable data.

  • ydataEst – 1D actual values of dependent variable data.

  • step (int) – The bin width for the independent variable data. Default is 10.

  • saveLoc (str) – A string for the location where the figure should be saved.

  • titleStr (str) – A string for the title of the figure to be generated. Assumes that a single number representing a figure number or wavelength is given.

  • normalize (Bool) – Controls whether the RMSE is normalized or not. Default is False.

Returns:

  • binCenters (list) – The bin centers for the dependent variable data.

  • RMSE (list) – The RMSE values for each bin.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.corrCol(myData, otherData, saveLoc=None)[source]

Given two sets of data, find the correlation between them. If the first set of data is multidimensional, correlate it with the second set by column. This function requires that ‘otherData’ is 1D and equivalent to the lengths of the columns of ‘myData’. Otherwise, if ‘myData’ is 1D, it must be the same length as ‘otherData’.

Parameters:

  • myData (numpy.ndarray) – The dependent variable data.

  • otherData (numpy.ndarray) – The independent variable data.

  • saveLoc (str) – A location where to save figures of the correlations. Optional argument. Default is None.

Returns:

fitParams – A poly1d object for the fit of the data. The last element is Pearson’s R.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.find_exp(number) → int[source]
Parameters:

number (float) – A float of any precision.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.find_nearest(array, value)[source]

Given an array, find the index and value of an item closest to a supplied value.

Parameters:

  • array (numpy.ndarray) – An array of values over which to search.

  • value (float, int, str, datetime) – A value for which the closest value will be searched for.

Returns:

  • idx (int) – The index of the nearest value.

  • array[idx] (float, int, str, datetime) – The actual value.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.firstNonNan(listfloats)[source]

Find the index of the first non-NaN value in a given sequence.

Parameters:

listfloats (arraylike) – A sequence of floats to search over.

Returns:

  • item (float) – The element that is the first non-NaN value.

  • idx (int) – The index corresponding to the first non-NaN value.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.forecast(y, coefs, trend_coefs, steps, exog=None)[source]

Produce linear minimum MSE forecast [taken from statsmodels.tsa.vector_ar.var_model.py]

Parameters:

  • y (ndarray) – Input data. (k_ar x neqs)

  • coefs (numpy.ndarray) – Coefficients for the model. (k_ar x neqs x neqs)

  • trend_coefs (ndarray (1 x neqs) or (neqs)) – Coefficients for the trend component. (1 x neqs) or (neqs)

  • steps (int) – Number of forecasts to make.

  • exog (numpy.ndarray) – Exogeneous (external) covariates to use during forecasting. (trend_coefs.shape[1] x neqs)

Returns:

forecasts – Predictions. (steps x neqs)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Notes

Lütkepohl p. 37

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.forecastInversion(forecastData, history, lastDiff, trend, window)[source]

Designed to operate on the output of the statsmodels VAR package. Takes a forecast generated by a VAR model, and for each sample in the forecast, inverts the forecast to obtain the actual prediction. Essentially, this function takes forecasts generated for non-stationary data that has been transformed to stationary data, and inverts it in order to give the non-stationary forecast result.

Parameters:

  • forecastData (numpy.ndarray) – An n x m array of forecasts, where n is the number of forecasts and m is the variable.

  • history (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D array of training data which was used to generate the forecastData.

  • lastDiff (numpy.ndarray) – A 1 x m array of the most recent differences for all of the variables.

  • trend (numpy.ndarray) – An 2D array of historical trend data for the non-stationary version of the data.

  • window (int) – The window over which the historical trend was calculated (assumes some sort of centered average was done).

Returns:

invertedForecastDataNew – The inverted forecasted data.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.fractionalDOY(myDatetime)[source]

Convert a generic datetime object into a float corresponding to the fractional day of the year.

Parameters:

myDatetime (datetime.datetime) – A datetime object.

Returns:

fracDOY – A float corresponding to the fractional Day of the Year, with the decimal portion included to show contributions from the time of day in hours, minutes, and seconds.

Return type:

float

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.gapify(timeseries, bad_value=999, replace_val=nan)[source]

Take a timeseries and replace the bad values (signified by ‘bad_values’) with NaNs, unless otherwise desired.

Parameters:

  • timestamps (arraylike) – A 1D list or array of timestamps.

  • bad_values (int or float) – A float or int corresponding to the bad values to be ‘gapped out’. Default is 999.

  • replace_val (int, float, NaN, or None) – An int, float, NaN, or Nonetype describing what will replace the bad values.

Returns:

The gapified 1D data.

Return type:

return gappedData:

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.get_cc(array1, array2, normalize=True)[source]

Compute the cross-correlation of two 1D arrays of the same length.

Parameters:

  • array2 (numpy.ndarray) – A 1D array of length n.

Returns:

c – The normalized correlation of the two arrays.

Return type:

float

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.imputeData(timestamps, values, method='mean', bad_values=nan)[source]

Given timeseries data, impute bad values and returned the cleaned data.

Parameters:

  • timestamps (arraylike) – A 1D list or array of timestamps.

  • values (arraylike) – A 1D list or array of timeseries data.

  • method (str) – A string indicating the method to be used. If ‘mean’, ‘median’, ‘most_frequent’, or ‘constant’, uses the SimpleImputer routine from sklearn. If ‘gam’, uses a Generalized Additive Model to fill in the data. If ‘gpr’, use Gaussian Process Regression to perform imputation. Otherwise, cubic spline interpolation is used for imputation.

  • bad_values (float, int, or NaN (type)) – The type of the data you wish to impute.

Returns:

  • cleanTimes (numpy.ndarray) – The timestamps corresponding to the cleaned data. This will differ from ‘timestamps’ if and only if some data are necessarily excluded by the chosen imputation method. For example, the edges of the data are often removed when the cubic spline interpolation is used for imputation, to avoid Runge’s phenomenon.

  • cleanData (numpy.ndarray) – The cleaned 1D timeseries.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.linear(x, a, b)[source]

A generic linear function for fitting lines with.

Parameters:

  • x (int, float, or arraylike) – An independent variable.

  • a (int or float) – The first model parameter - the coefficient.

  • b (int or float) – The second model parameter - the intercept term.

Returns:

y – The dependent variable.

Return type:

int, float, or arraylike

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.mycorrelate2d(df, normalized=False)[source]

Compute the correlation matrix from 2D data, where each row is cross correlated with the others. This function handles NaN values by ignoring them.

Parameters:

  • df (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D array of dimensions n x m.

  • normalized (bool) – Determines whether the resulting correlation matrix is normalized. Default is False.

Returns:

ccm – The [normalized] cross-correlation matrix.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.newbins(wavelengths, data, bins, zero=False, interpolation=False)[source]

Rebin data according to a user-defined binning scheme.

Returns:

  • wavelengths (arraylike) – The wavelengths of the native data. Units should be in nm.

  • data (arraylike) – The native data to be rebinned. Assumes each row is an observation and each column is a bin.

  • bins (dict) – A dictionary containing the left-ward wavelength bin limits (first key) and the right-ward wavelength bin limits (right key). Units should be in Angstroms.

  • zero (bool) – Controls whether a wavelength bin is ‘zeroed’ out after it is considered. Default is False.

  • interpolation (bool) – Controls whether interpolation or 4-nm centered windowed averaging is used to handle singular emission lines. Default is False, corresponding to the windowed averaging.

Returns:

  • newWaves (arraylike) – The wavelength boundaries of the new binning scheme.

  • newData (arraylike) – The values of the rebinned data.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.normalize(myData, axis=-1)[source]

Normalize data with respect to the mean, along the axis specified by the user.

Parameters:

  • myData (numpy.ndarray) – A 1d or 2d array of data.

  • axis (int) – The axis along which to perform normalization with respect to the mean. Default is -1.

Returns:

normedData – The normalized data.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Parameters:

directory (str) – A string that is the directory to be created, with respect to the current location.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.plotHist(data, bins, color, saveLoc=None, labels=None, logScale=None, density=True)[source]

Given data and bins, plot a histogram and fit a distribution to it.

Parameters:

  • data (arraylike) – 1D data to make a histogram with.

  • bins (arraylike) – The bins with which to bin the data.

  • color (str) – The color of the histogram data that will be in the plot.

  • saveLoc (str) – A string containing the location with which to save the file.

  • labels (list) – A 3-element list containing string for the xlabel, ylabel, and the title.

  • logScale (bool) – If ‘x’, scales the x-axis on a log scale. If ‘y’, scales the y-axis on a log scale. If ‘both’, scales both.

  • density (bool) – If True, computes the density curve of the histogram. If False, simply fits a skew normal distribution to the data.

Returns:

fig – A figure object containing the histogram.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.readCLS(filename)[source]

Load in flare-corrected, Sun-Earth distance adjusted flux values recorded by the Collecte Localisation Satellites (CLS).

Parameters:

  • filename (str) – The location of the data file.

  • times (list) – The datetimes for each data value.

Returns:

data – The solar flux data for F30, F15, F10.7, F8, and F3.2.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.readFISM2(fname)[source]

Given a FISM2 netcdf file, read it in and output a .dat file with the same format as the .dat files here: https://github.com/aaronjridley/GITM/tree/master/srcData/FISM

Parameters:

fname (str) – The location of the FISM2 file to read in.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.rebin(wavelengths, data, resolution, limits=None, factor=None, zero=True, unc=False)[source]

Rebin 2D [irradiance/flux] data, where each row is a complete spectrum, and each column is a specific wavelength bin. Do the rebinning according to a desired resolution, and restrict the returned information to wavelength boundaries set by the user.

Parameters:

  • wavelengths (arraylike) – A list of wavelengths at which each irradiance value is taken.

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D array of spectrum data (irradiances or fluxes).

  • resolution (float or dict) – The desired spectral resolution of the rebinned data. Units must be in nanometers. If argument is a dict, the key ‘short’ should contain wavelength boundaries for the beginning of bins, and the key ‘long’ should contain wavelength boundaries for the ending of bins. These boundaries should be in Angstroms.

  • limits (list) – A list of two elements, where the first is a lower limit for wavelengths and the second is an upper limit for wavelengths, both in units of nanometers.

  • factor (int) – A factor by which to upsample the data before performing rebinning. Tends to make the binning much more accurate, due to the use of integrals. Default is None.

  • zero (bool) – Controls whether singular lines are set to a value of zero after they are extracted. Default is True.

  • unc (bool) – Indicates whether or not uncertainties are being rebinned. If so, they will be combined in each bin using an interpolation method.

Returns:

  • newWaves (numpy.ndarray) – The centers of the wavelength bins corresponding to the rebinned data.

  • newData (numpy.ndarray) – The rebinned data as a 2D array, arranged like the input data but at the new wavelength resolution.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.rollingAverage(myData, window_length=1, impute_edges=True, center=True)[source]

Using pandas, compute a rolling average of over ‘data’ using a window length of ‘windowlength’. Sets the leading and trailing windows to the values of the original data.

Parameters:

  • myData (arraylike) – The data over which to compute the rolling average.

  • window_length (int) – The size of the window over which to average.

  • impute_edges (bool) – A boolean determining whether the edges will be interpolated. Default is True.

  • center (bool) – A boolean determining whether the centered average will be used.

Returns:

rolled – The rolling averaged data.

Return type:

arraylike

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.rollingStd(myData, window_length=2, axis=-1)[source]

Given some data, compute the rolling standard deviation. If the data is two dimensional, compute the rolling standard deviation along a specific axis of the data (specified by the user).

Parameters:

  • myData (arraylike) – The data over which to compute the rolling average.

  • window_length (int) – The size of the window over which to average. Default is 2.

  • axis (int) – For 2D data, the axis along which to compute the rolling standard deviation. Defaults is -1.

Returns:

stdData – The rolling standard deviation values of the data.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

  • divisor (int or float) – The number which the result must be an integer multiple of.

  • direction (str) – Either ‘down’ or ‘up’. Specifies whether rounding should be done up or down/

Returns:

rounded – The resulting number.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.solomonRebin(solomonIrr)[source]

Given some irradiance in the Solomon Bins, do a simple rebinning procedure to simply sum the irradiance in the overlapping bins, so that the resulting spectra can be plotted rather easily.

Parameters:

solomonIrr (numpyn.ndarray) – An array of irradiance in the Solomon Bins. Rows are observations and columns are wavelength bins.

Returns:

solomonIrr_for_plotting – The rebinned irradiance.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.uniformSample(xdata, ydata, cadence)[source]

Given some data with associated time stamps, resample the data so that the data have the time resolution equal to the given cadence.

Parameters:

  • xdata (arraylike) – A list of time stamps.

  • ydata (arraylike) – A list of data/values associated with the time stamps.

  • cadence (int) – An integer denoting (in hours) the desired time cadence of the data.

Returns:

  • uniformXdata (numpy.ndarray) – A uniformly-sampled array of datetimes.

  • uniformYdata (numpy.ndarray) – A uniformly-sampled array of corresponding data/values.

EUVpy.tools.toolbox.urlObtain(url, fname)[source]

Download a file from a URL. If the file already exists, don’t download it; just print the location of the existing file. Returns nothing.

Parameters:

  • url (str) – The URL where the file is to be downloaded from.

  • fname (str) – The filename which the downloaded file will be saved to.
